SEC Delays Decision On Truth Social ETF The United States Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has extended the review period for the Truth Social Bitcoin ETF until September. headline: A 2035 Vision: Will Bitcoin Hit the Million-Dollar Milestone?
summary: As Bitcoin begins its third decade of existence, investors and enthusiasts around the globe are struggling with one breathtaking question: How much will one Bitcoin be worth in 2035? Ten years from now, as cryptocurrencies are deeply woven into the texture of finance and technology, long-term targets for the world's biggest virtual asset are both ambitious and hotly debated. Consensus 2025: Million-Dollar Bitcoin Enters Mainstream Predictions being taken with grains of salt and all, one thing is sure: most forecasts up until 2025 are in agreement that the value of Bitcoin as of 2035 might be historical, even a record-breaker. Numerous comprehensive surveys point to $1 million per Bitcoin as a default scenario for 2035, with some projections even surpassing that. A July 2025 report by Finder that polled 24 cryptocurrency researchers and analysts estimates the average price of Bitcoin at the end of 2035 to be $1.02 million. It is not an outlier: many other models and reports‚Äîranging from mainstream financial news outlets to technical and adoption-based analysis‚Äîagree on this seven-figure number, and some estimate prices even higher for the same timeline, to $1.3‚Äì1.8 million or even more. What's Behind the Mega-Bullish Estimates? Institutional and Governmental Adoption Among the biggest tailwinds behind Bitcoin's price potential is growing institutional and even national adoption. Over the last five years, giant corporations, hedge funds, and even nation-states have come to accumulate Bitcoin as a treasury reserve asset. Panelists in long-range forecasts cite this ever-broadening base of ‚Äùstrong hands‚Äù ‚Äì entities that buy for the long haul ‚Äì repeatedly as one of the most potent forces pushing the price higher. ‚ÄùAs governments continue to print fiat money at unsustainably high levels, people will look for alternative ways of storing value. Gold has been a store of value for centuries and bitcoin is a better version of gold,‚Äù one industry expert said. Bitcoin as ‚ÄùDigital Gold‚Äù Most analysts think Bitcoin will ultimately outrank or at least match gold's aggregate market capitalization‚Äîa situation that alone would justify a $1 million plus valuation per coin. This ‚Äùdigital gold‚Äù narrative is held commonly now by investors from Wall Street to sovereign wealth funds, so fresh capital may increase consistently over the next ten years, particularly if macroeconomic uncertainty or inflationary pressures continue. Scarcity and Halving Cycles Bitcoin's inherent monetary quality‚Äîits fixed supply of 21 million coins‚Äînever changes, and periodic ‚Äùhalving‚Äù diminishes new supply over time. By 2035, the number of new-issue bitcoins minted each year will have declined considerably, further enhancing scarcity and price pressure. Technological Maturity and Utility The Bitcoin network will be more powerful, with superior transaction layers, increased processing power, and widespread adoption across financial products. Mainstream adoption may be less volatile and more due to actual economic usage if there is more secure and efficient infrastructure. Dissent and Conservative Models There has been a broadly bullish view, but some experts propose more conservative estimates by pointing out the maturing but still volatile state of crypto markets. headline: Bitcoin: Unveiling Its Crucial Role as a Hedge Against the U.S. Deficit
summary: BitcoinWorld Bitcoin: Unveiling Its Crucial Role as a Hedge Against the U.S. Deficit In a surprising turn that has captivated the financial world, CNBC‚Äôs Mad Money host Jim Cramer, a figure often associated with skepticism towards cryptocurrencies, has publicly declared that ‚ÄòBitcoin is a hedge against the U.S. budget deficit.‚Äô This bold statement marks a significant shift in perception from a mainstream financial commentator, highlighting a growing acknowledgment of Bitcoin‚Äôs potential role in global economics. For anyone keenly observing the evolving landscape of digital assets, this endorsement suggests a deeper narrative unfolding around the utility of a Bitcoin hedge in an increasingly uncertain economic climate. Why is Jim Cramer Calling Bitcoin a ‚ÄòBitcoin Hedge‚Äô? Jim Cramer‚Äôs recent comments, as reported by U.Today, signal a notable evolution in his stance on Bitcoin. Historically, Cramer has been known for his cautious, sometimes even critical, views on cryptocurrencies. His latest pronouncement, however, positions Bitcoin not merely as a speculative asset but as a strategic financial instrument. But what exactly prompted this change of heart, and why does he see Bitcoin as a viable Bitcoin hedge against something as fundamental as the U.S. budget deficit? Economic Hardship and Political Instability: Cramer posits that Bitcoin could offer a shield for nations and individuals against the adverse effects of economic hardship and political instability. A ballooning national debt can lead to inflation, currency devaluation, and a loss of confidence in traditional financial systems. In such scenarios, an asset that operates outside government control and traditional banking infrastructure gains appeal. Decentralization and Scarcity: Unlike fiat currencies, which can be printed in unlimited quantities by central banks, Bitcoin has a capped supply of 21 million coins. This inherent scarcity, combined with its decentralized nature, makes it resistant to inflationary pressures and political manipulation, characteristics that are highly desirable in a hedging asset. A Personal Anecdote: Cramer reinforced his argument by recalling the story of an anonymous worker who, five years ago, purchased Bitcoin when it was trading under $50,000. This individual now enjoys financial freedom, a testament to Bitcoin‚Äôs long-term appreciation. Such stories, while anecdotal, resonate deeply and illustrate the transformative potential of early adoption, underscoring the power of a strategic Bitcoin hedge . Understanding the U.S. Budget Deficit: A Backdrop for the Bitcoin Hedge Argument To fully grasp the significance of Cramer‚Äôs statement, it‚Äôs crucial to understand the context of the U.S. budget deficit. The budget deficit occurs when government expenditures exceed its revenues, leading to an accumulation of national debt. Persistent and large deficits can have several profound economic implications: Inflationary Pressures: Governments often finance deficits by borrowing or, in some cases, by increasing the money supply. The latter can lead to inflation, eroding the purchasing power of a currency and devaluing savings. Currency Devaluation: A country with a large and growing debt may see its currency weaken against others, making imports more expensive and potentially reducing the nation‚Äôs economic standing on the global stage. Economic Instability: High levels of debt can lead to higher interest rates, reduced government spending flexibility, and increased risk of economic crises, potentially impacting everything from employment to investment. In this environment, investors and nations seek assets that can preserve value and offer stability. Gold has traditionally served this role, but Cramer‚Äôs argument suggests Bitcoin is emerging as a digital alternative, providing a modern form of a Bitcoin hedge . Beyond the National Level: Bitcoin as a Personal ‚ÄòBitcoin Hedge‚Äô While Cramer‚Äôs focus was on nations, the concept of Bitcoin as a hedge extends powerfully to individuals. For many, the idea of a Bitcoin hedge against personal financial hardship or the erosion of savings due to inflation is highly compelling. Consider the following ways Bitcoin can act as a personal safeguard: Feature of Bitcoin How it Acts as a Hedge Scarcity (21 Million Cap) Protects against inflation and debasement of value, unlike fiat currencies that can be printed infinitely. Decentralization Operates outside government or central bank control, reducing political risk and censorship. Global Accessibility Can be accessed and transferred anywhere in the world, offering financial sovereignty, especially in regions with unstable local currencies. Divisibility Can be divided into tiny units (satoshi), making it accessible for investments of all sizes. The anonymous worker‚Äôs story is a vivid example of this personal hedge in action. By strategically investing in Bitcoin when others might have hesitated, they secured a degree of financial independence that traditional investments might not have provided in the same timeframe. This highlights Bitcoin‚Äôs potential not just as a speculative gamble, but as a long-term store of value for those seeking a robust Bitcoin hedge . Navigating the Waters: Challenges and Considerations for the Bitcoin Hedge While the narrative of Bitcoin as a hedge is gaining traction, it‚Äôs essential to approach it with a balanced perspective. The cryptocurrency market, including Bitcoin, comes with its own set of challenges and considerations that investors must be aware of: Volatility: Bitcoin is known for its price swings, which can be significant. While it has shown long-term appreciation, short-term volatility can be daunting for some investors. Regulatory Uncertainty: The regulatory landscape for cryptocurrencies is still evolving globally. Changes in regulations can impact Bitcoin‚Äôs accessibility, utility, and perceived value. Technological Risks: While Bitcoin‚Äôs underlying technology (blockchain) is robust, risks associated with cybersecurity, hacking of exchanges, or loss of private keys remain. Market Manipulation: Despite its decentralized nature, the relatively smaller market cap compared to traditional assets can make Bitcoin more susceptible to large-scale market manipulations. These challenges do not negate Bitcoin‚Äôs potential as a Bitcoin hedge but underscore the importance of due diligence, risk management, and a long-term investment horizon. It is not a guaranteed shield, but rather a tool within a diversified financial strategy. Actionable Insights: How to Approach the Bitcoin Hedge For those considering Bitcoin as a component of their financial strategy, especially as a hedge against economic uncertainties, here are some actionable insights: Educate Yourself Thoroughly: Before investing, understand how Bitcoin works, its underlying technology, and the factors that influence its price. Knowledge is your best defense against market volatility and misinformation. Start Small and Diversify: Do not put all your eggs in one basket. Allocate a small, manageable portion of your portfolio to Bitcoin that you are comfortable losing. A diversified portfolio is key to managing risk. Adopt a Long-Term Perspective: The concept of a Bitcoin hedge is typically a long-term strategy. Avoid trying to time the market. Instead, focus on Bitcoin‚Äôs fundamental properties as a store of value over extended periods. Secure Your Assets: Use reputable exchanges and consider hardware wallets for storing significant amounts of Bitcoin to protect against cyber threats. Stay Informed: Keep abreast of global economic trends, regulatory developments, and technological advancements in the crypto space. This will help you make informed decisions about your Bitcoin hedge strategy. Jim Cramer‚Äôs shift in perspective is a powerful indicator that Bitcoin is maturing beyond a niche interest into a serious contender for a role in mainstream finance. His acknowledgment of Bitcoin as a hedge against the U.S. deficit is not just a passing comment but a signal that traditional financial thinking is beginning to grapple with the disruptive and protective potential of digital assets. In conclusion, Jim Cramer‚Äôs surprising endorsement of Bitcoin as a hedge against the U.S. budget deficit marks a pivotal moment in the ongoing conversation about cryptocurrency‚Äôs role in the global economy. While challenges remain, the narrative of Bitcoin as a robust financial shield against inflation and instability is gaining significant momentum. Whether for nations seeking to safeguard their economies or individuals striving for financial freedom, the concept of a Bitcoin hedge is rapidly evolving from a radical idea into a compelling strategy worth serious consideration. Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) What exactly is the U.S. budget deficit? The U.S. budget deficit occurs when the federal government‚Äôs total expenditures exceed its total revenues during a fiscal year. This shortfall is typically covered by borrowing, which adds to the national debt. A persistent deficit can lead to concerns about inflation, currency devaluation, and long-term economic stability. How can Bitcoin act as a ‚Äòhedge‚Äô against economic instability? Bitcoin can act as a hedge due to its decentralized nature, fixed supply (21 million coins), and global accessibility. Unlike fiat currencies, it cannot be arbitrarily printed by governments, making it resistant to inflation caused by monetary expansion. Its independence from traditional financial systems also provides a refuge during periods of political or economic instability, offering a non-sovereign store of value. Is Jim Cramer always bullish on Bitcoin? No, Jim Cramer has historically been known for his skepticism and sometimes critical views on Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies. His recent statement calling Bitcoin a hedge against the U.S. deficit represents a notable and somewhat surprising bullish turn, highlighting a significant shift in his perspective. What are the main risks of using Bitcoin as a hedge? Key risks include high price volatility, regulatory uncertainty across different jurisdictions, potential for market manipulation, and technological risks such as cybersecurity threats or the loss of private keys. While Bitcoin offers unique hedging properties, it‚Äôs crucial for investors to understand and mitigate these risks. How does Bitcoin compare to traditional hedges like gold? Like gold, Bitcoin is considered a scarce asset that can act as a store of value independent of government policies. However, Bitcoin offers advantages in terms of digital portability, divisibility, and potentially higher returns, though it also carries greater volatility.
